La sra. Flavia A. tiene una cantina,invirtio el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo y mercaderias de modo a ir surtiendo y ofrecer mas variedad a sus clientes.

La sra. Luciana L. se dedica a la venta de Comestibles, invirtrio el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboracion de los comestibles, pudiendo asi ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes y  aumentar su ingreso.

La sra. Cynthia G. se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir,  invirtio el dinero en la compra de esa prendas en general, logrando obtener mayor variedas para sus clientes.

La sra. Vielva A. se dedideca a la venta de comestibles, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboracion de los mismos ofreciendo calidad y variedad a su clientela.

La sra. Dora S.  tiene un copiten, invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercederias para surtir su negocio de ese modo obtiene mayor varias para ofrecer al clente.

La sra. Rocio Fernanadez de se dedica a la venta de Bijuoteri, invirtio el dinero en la compra de esos articulos ofreciendo articulos varios a sus clientes.


La sra. Nanci M. se dedica a la venta de prendas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de  prendas de vestir en general , obteniendo si mayor variedad de prendas para ofrecer a sus clientes.

La sra. Mirian A.  es peluquera y masajista, invirtio el  dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo, obreciendo comodidad y buen servicio a su clientela.

 La sra. Daisy Y.  se dedica a la venta de bebidas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de bebidas varias pudiendo asi surtir su negocio y ofrecer mas variedad a sus clientes.

La sra.Cynthia E. es costurera, invirtio el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo, de esa manera aumentar su produccion
texts.en:
The present committee was started by Marta E., who invited and organized her friends to become a part of the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras program.

Marta E. sells silverware. She invests her money by purchasing more products so she can offer a wider variety to her clients.

Carmen E. sells cosmetics. She purchases products wholesale so that she can obtain higher earnings and offer a wide variety of products.

Mercedes E. Macen sells groceries. She also buys and sells supplies for food preparation to increase the quality of her customer care.

Ramona E. sells clothing. She invests her money by purchasing additional products so she can offer a wider variety to her clients.

Zully E. sells cosmetics. She invests her money by purchasing additional products so she can offer a wider variety to her clients.

Estelvina A. sells drinks. She invests her money by purchasing additional products so she can offer a wider variety to her clients.

Patricia O. sells clothing. She purchases different types of clothing so she can attract a wider clientele.

Flavia A. owns a cantina. She purchases necessary items for her business and fashionable merchandise so that she can offer her clients more variety.

Luciana L. sells groceries. She also purchases and sells other ingredients needed to prepare food so she can offer her clients variety and increase her income.

Cynthia G. sells clothing. She invests her money by purchasing general assortments of clothings so she can have more variety for her clients.

Vielva A. sells groceries. She purchases and sells ingredients needed to prepare food so she can offer quality and variety to her clients.

Dora S. owns a copiten. She invests her money by purchasing additional merchandise to stock her business and offer more variety to her clients.

Rocio Fernanadez sells jewelry. She invests her money by purchasing additional articles so that she can offer her clients variety.

Nanci M. sells clothing. She invests her money by purchasing general assortments of clothings so she can have more variety for her clients.

Mirian A. is a hairdresser and masseuse. She invests her money by purchasing necessary items for her work so she can offer her clients comfort and good service.

Daisy Y. sells beverages. She invests her money by purchasing a variety of beverages so she can stock her business and offer more variety to her clients.

Cynthia E. is a seamstress. She invests her money by purchasing necessary items for her work so she can increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing, silverware, cosmetic and haircare items, items for food preparation (eggs, bread, vegetables, fruit, etc.); beverages

loans.name: Nuevo Porvenir Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra el centro focal Panamericana  a éste pertenece, la asociación “Nuevo Porvenir”, integrada por 10 mujeres, trabajan junto a Pro-Mujer hace tres años aproximadamente.
La mayoría en el grupo son casadas y afirman que necesitan ayudar a sus parejas en la economía del hogar, ya que tienen un promedio de 4 niños. 
Diversas son las actividades de este grupo algunas  venden ropa, comida, cosméticos, además  se dedican a la publicidad y también tienen tiendas de consumo como es el caso de Valentina. Ellas precisan capital para incrementar su mercadería  de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para sus familias.
texts.en:
In the city of El Alto, there is a center called Panamericana. It is to this center that the "Nuevo Porvenir" association, a group made up of 10 women, belongs. For approximately three years, they have been working together with Pro-Mujer. The majority of the group is married and affirm that they need to help their partners with the household costs, since they each have about 4 children. The group has a variety of businesses. They sell clothing, food, cosmetics and work in advertising. Some women, such as Valentina, own stores. The women of the group need capital to increase their merchandise and generate higher incomes for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
At 61 years old, Lolita S. owns a sari-sari (variety or mini grocery) store. She is a hardworking woman who is married to Plaxido, a carpenter with a meager income. They are blessed with four children. She started her business with a small amount of capital from her vegetable vending. She used and managed her money well until she could open another project, the sari-sari store, as their major source of income.

As of now, two of Lolita's children are working abroad and she is able to receive a monthly allotment as support. She needs a capital of PHP 20,000 to buy additional inventory. She looks forward to her two daughters finishing college and establishing their own careers.

loans.use: Purchase of grocery items

loans.name: Sulemana

texts.en:
Sulemana M. is thirty-nine years old, but his face looks younger. He is married and a father with four children. He lives at Takroase, a mining community at Akim Oda, in the eastern region of Ghana. Sulemana is very resourceful and committed to his family, especially in the area of their education. He is a buyer and seller of gold and diamonds. He makes a living with this business and has worked in the field of mining for fifteen years. He has many suppliers in the village from whom he purchases the gold and the diamonds. Through the relationship he has with the suppliers, he always has stock to sell. He mostly deals with foreigners who come from abroad to buy his gold and diamonds.

Ghana is rich in natural resources. It is a fact that the quality of diamonds and gold from Ghana is rated as one of the best as compared to other countries. This has created increased demand from his buyers, but he is not able to meet those demands. He buys the gold and diamonds at high prices from the suppliers, but, because of the economic situation he now finds himself in, he is not able to buy more. He is requesting loan support to buy more gold and diamonds to supply his exclusive customers. He was thinking about forming a partnership so that he could buy more, but there are none to find. Sulemana has a diamond in his palm in this picture. He would be grateful for your support. He belongs to the village bank called Divine.

loans.use: To buy gold and diamonds to resell.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en: Claudia A. is fifty-eight years old and a widow with nine children. She is a good member of the Kiva field partner, Paglaum MPC, in their micro-finance program.  She pays her obligation on time during the center weekly meeting. Recently, she applied for a loan of $225 for additional capital for her fish vending business. She is very thankful to Paglaum for the loan assistance that helps her to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy  fish to sell.

loans.name: María Estela

texts.es:
La señora María Estela O. se dedica arduamente a su negocio de tienda en general el cual es comercializada por ella misma habiéndola desarrollado siendo Ceprodel el pilar que le ha brindado créditos para su negocio. 

Hoy en día ha mejorado las condiciones de su negocio habiendo adquirido vitrinas y estantes donde exhibir sus productos. Espera en que Ceprodel le brindará un crédito para la compra de los productos y así salir adelante en su negocio en su localidad.
texts.en:
María Estela O. works arduously in her general store. She advertises the store on her own and works to improve it through the help of Ceprodel, a pillar that has brought her credit for her business. At present, she has improved her business by installing display cases and shelves to display her products. She hopes that Ceprodel will help her obtain credit to purchase merchandise and make her business successful.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mariza

texts.es:
La Sra. Mariza González nació en la ciudad de Juan de Mena. Ella vive desde hace más de diez años con el Sr. Flavio Emilio Antunez Vera quien también es oriundo de la ciudad de Juan de Mena y con quien tuvo dos hijos, ambos todavía menores. 

Ella se dedica a la confección de atuendos estudiantiles como buzos, shorts, uniformes entre otros, mientras que el sr. Flavio confecciona camperas de cuero. Gracias al primer crédito pudo terminar de ampliar su taller aunque hoy día todavía le falta algunas refacciones. El último crédito lo utilizó en la compra de rollos de tela, cuero para la fabricación de camperas y la reparación de su máquina.
texts.en:
Mariza González was born in the city of Juan de Mena. For over ten years, she has lived with Flavio Emilio Antunez Vera, who is also a native of Juan de Mena. Together, they have two children who are both still young. Mariza makes clothing for students such as tracksuits, shorts and uniforms, among other items, while Flavio makes leather jackets. Thanks to their first loan, they were able to finish the expansion of their workshop. At present, the building still needs some renovations. They used their most recent loan to purchase rolls of fabric and leather to make the jackets and to repair the machine.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cloth, leather for jackets, other production items and repair the machine

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice B. sells beans, groundnuts, millet and other food supplies at Akotokyir in Abura. Alice has received no formal education. She is married with two children and her husband is employed as a gardener. Alice has been selling beans, groundnuts and millet since 2006. She is responsible in her support of her husband by helping pay for housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy additional food supplies for resale.  Alice hopes to use her newly gained profits to expand the business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy additional food supplies to sell.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana G. is forty-seven years old. She is married and the mother of six children. Juliana is an entrepreneur, dynamic and very dedicated to her work. She got married twenty-three years ago. Three of her children are in senior high school and the other three are learning trades.

She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil for over three years. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits. Juliana produces the palm oil and sells it to food vendors for preparing their meals. She even treks to other villages to purchase finished goods when demand becomes very high. Her major business area is her neighboring country, Togo, in West Africa. She takes gallons of palm oil to be sold in Togo, and when she returns she brings foodstuffs like gari (fermented and dried cassava), maize, etc. and retails them in her community.

Prices of raw materials are very high, making it difficult for her to achieve her target. Loan support will help her to realize that dream. Juliana wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts fruits, and gallon containers to increase her efficiency in producing larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income for supporting her children's education. Juliana belongs to a village bank called ‘Divine’.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and gallon containers.

loans.name: Norman

texts.en:
Being a member of Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative, one of Kiva's field partners, is a great opportunity for Norman D.. He is thirty-one years old, married and lives at Upper Langcangan, Oroquieta City. He is a tricycle-taxi driver and his wife is a homemaker. 
    
Due to the global economic crisis, he felt strongly the need to have additional income besides what he earns  from driving. He joined the cooperative in order to get capital for his newly opened "sari-sari" (general) store. His wife will be the manager. Today, he wants a loan of $275 to buy additional goods to sell and to purchase a secondhand motorcab. He also plans to buy another motorcycle for hire.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for sari-sari

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina A. K. sells clothing and fabric in Abura. Paulina has received an education through Junior High School.  She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a trader. Paulina has been selling clothing and fabric for 12 years now. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses and support when there is any other need. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of clothing and fabric for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of  her trade in clothing and fabrics.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of clothing and fabric for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is 36 years old, divorced and the mother of two children. She divorced when she realized the husband was giving himself too much to alcohol and neglecting his family responsibilities. Currently, both her children are in school through the help of free compulsory education and a school feeding program. 

For three years, Mary has been selling grocery products on a table in her neighborhood to support her family. She says business is doing well and she therefore wants to use the loan to buy more products like tinned fish, tinned tomatoes, cocoa products and skimmed milk to increase her inventory. Mary believes the loan would help her increase her savings towards the welfare of her two children. Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Nkwagyedom’ which literally means "savior of the multitude".

loans.use: To buy more grocery products like tin fish, tin tomatoes, cocoa products, skimmed milk, vegetable oil, etc

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene T., 48 years of age, is married to Rico Tempura who is a laborer. They are blessed with five children and four of them are still studying.  Arlene decided to be part of a Paglaum coop so that she could get a loan of additional capital for her sari-sari or grocery store and for the capitalization of her new business of "chicharon" making. Chicharon is a popular food appetizer made with pork skins. 

Because the income of her husband is not enough to support  them, Arlene is very thankful to PMPC for the assistance.  It helps to provide for the daily financial needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy more stocks grocery items and ingredients for "chicharon" making

loans.name: Afi Enyonam

texts.fr: Madame est une femme mariée qui vit dans le quartier d’agoè Zongo. Elle a commencé en 2002 le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a ouvert une boutique qui s’appelle « ALLIANCE BOUTIQUE » dans laquelle elle exerce son activité. Elle est une fidèle cliente de WAGES  qui a déjà obtenu 02 crédits qu’elle a remboursé. Son stock de marchandises étant épuisé, elle sollicite son troisième crédit pour acheter 15 cartons de tomates en boîte, 10 bidons d’huile, 03 cartons de lait, 05 cartons de produits congelés. Elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est déclarant en douane, elle a 02 enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. K. is a married woman who lives in the Agoè Zongo neighborhood. She began selling groceries in 2002. She opened a little shop for this purpose that she calls « ALLIANCE BOUTIQUE ». She is a faithful client of WAGES who has already had 2 loans which she has reimbursed. Her stock of merchandise is expended so she is requesting her third loan to buy 15 cases of tinned tomatoes, 10 jerrycans of oil, 3 cases of milk, and 5 cases of frozen foods. She is married to a gentleman who is a customs officer, and she has 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Killa Group

texts.en:
The Killa (“Moon” in Quechua) Village Bank is a newly formed group of 12 people (three men and nine women) who live in Cusco, Peru. The group is very excited about starting its first loan cycle. On Tuesday night, they celebrated with a toast and cookies. The group’s president urged the group to work together and show solidarity with members who might need a little extra help so as to avoid any potential problems in the future.

The group members all work in the city of Cusco and are involved with a variety of different businesses. Luis H. is an electrical technician and works independently servicing hotels, private homes and Internet cafes. He plans to use his loan of 800 soles to buy an oscilloscope, which costs 1,100 soles. (He will add 300 soles of his savings to his loan money).

Catherine Eulalia C., the group’s president, works as a cashier at a local money exchange. She also runs her own ice-cream shop as a side business and plans to use her loan of 700 soles to purchase cones and different flavors of ice cream.

Rosa runs a café called “Cuántica Mun,” where she sells salchipapas (French fries served with hot dog slices), milanesas (breaded chicken patties) and other snacks. She has had her restaurant for almost two years now. She plans to use her loan of 800 soles to help her open up a laundrymat in San Blas, an artisans’ neighborhood very popular with tourists.

Flor de Maria P. also has her own bar/restaurant in central Cusco, where she serves international food as well as local dishes like lomo saltado (beef sautéed with French fries and vegetables and served on rice), stews and steaks. She plans to use her loan of 800 soles to buy beer for the restaurant and to expand the kitchen.

Several other group members sell cell-phone calls. They plan to use their loans to add more calling credit to their phones.

The group has pledged to work together and repay its Kiva loan on time and in full.

loans.use: Buy oscilloscope, cooking ingredients, add credit to cell phones

loans.name: Siempre Amigas Group

texts.es:
La asociación “siempre amigas” pertenece al centro focal Panamericana, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos trabajan muy responsables en todas sus actividades de grupo.
Casi todas casadas, con familias numerosas nos cuentan que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares sobrepasan al ingreso que obtienen en sus negocios ya que sus familias son numerosas y sus  hijos van creciendo aumentando sus necesidades.
La mayor parte del grupo se dedica a  comercio de productos variados, venta que la realizan en puestos fijos y también de  forma ambulante, por ejemplo venden abarrotes,  queso, verduras, productos de limpieza, también se dedican al tejido de mantas . Ellas quieren ampliar sus ventas para esto necesitan capital para poder comprar productos en mayor cantidad. De esta manera  mejorarían sus ingresos y su estabilidad económica en sus hogares
texts.en:
The "friends forever" association belongs to the Pan-American center. With the help of it's loan officer, the group is very responsible in all of its activities. Nearly all of the group members are married, and many have families. Most of the daily costs of running a home exceed the income earned from their businesses, as the group members have many children with growing needs. Most group members sell various products from their stores and also on the street. For example, some sell groceries, cheese, vegetables, and cleaning products. They also weave blankets. The members would like to improve their sales and therefore need capital to buy supplies wholesale. In this way they'll improve their income and the economic stability of their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: They need to buy products

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana O. is a 34 year-old local restaurant operator. She is married and blessed with four children. Two of her children are in school and the others are working. Diana is very supportive of her family and committed to the service of her maker. In her restaurant she prepares and sells local foods like "fufu" and "banku." Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and taken with all kinds of soup.  Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is taken with hot pepper or soup.Diana has been in business for the past 7 years.  Diana says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her meet her production expenditures. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. Diana belongs to a village bank called ‘Bisa Nyame’ which literally means "Ask God".

loans.use: To buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 33 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their 16-month-old son. Edith has a degree in psychology and used to work in rural communities as a psychologist doing preventative work in counseling and drug and STD/STI prevention; at the same time, she ran a small empanada (a filled savory pastry) business on the side. When her son was born, she decided to dedicate herself exclusively to making empanadas, since it became difficult to travel to rural communities with him in tow. Her parents have their own empanada business, and let Edith use their stove.

She bakes different kinds of empanadas, including meat, cheese, chicken, hot dog and mixed varieties, and sells each one for 60 centimos apiece (US 20 cents). She makes about 100 empanadas each day, depending on order volume, and distributes them to local schools or sells them herself outside of the schools. She earns 15 to 20 soles in profits for every 100 empanadas she sells. Though she usually works alone, Edith’s husband helps her in his free time (he works as a security guard).

Edith is requesting a loan of 1000 soles to buy butter and flour for her empanadas. She would like to open her own cake bakery in the future, though she has also thought about going back to work as a psychologist once her son is a bit older.

Edith has been a member of Asociacion Arariwa for the past five years. A friend convinced her to join a village bank, and she hasn’t left since. She says that her empanada business has expanded significantly since she first started taking out small loans. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan on time and in full.

loans.use: Buy butter and flour to make empanadas

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is the president of the Sumac Soncco (“Loving Heart” in Quechua) Village Bank. She is 42 years old and married with three children who are 23, 15 and 11 years old. Rosa sells backpacks from a stand at the Paraiso Commercial Center in the city of Cusco. She has been in this business for eight years. She usually works alone, though her children sometimes help her when they are not in school.

Rosa is requesting a loan of 1000 soles to buy more backpacks from local providers in Cusco. Her goal for the future is to start sewing and selling her own backpacks. She has been an Arariwa client for one year now, and is starting her first loan cycle as group president. As president, she will call meetings to order, enforce the group’s internal regulations (imposing fines on members who arrive late, designating certain members to cook a meal for each meeting, etc.) and generally ensure that the group is working together smoothly.

Rosa has pledged to repay this loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Buy backpacks

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina A. is thirty seven years old. She is married and the mother of four children. Currently all the children are in school. She loves selling goods, the business which is the source of her livelihood.  Selina resides in Takroase, a farming and a mining community in the in the eastern region of Ghana. She was born and bred there with family members. Selina lives in the family house together with the husband. Her husband buys and sells diamonds. She has been selling food stuffs like tubers of yam, beans and peanuts etc. for twelve years to support her family. She treks to nearby farming communities  to buy her stock of yam. Sometimes she spends days in the villages just to get a large quantity of food stuffs. This saves her from the middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, Selina wants to buy bulk tubers of yam, peanuts and beans etc. to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school.Selina belongs to a village bank called ‘Nkwagyedom’ which literally means "savior of the multitude".

loans.use: She wants the loan to buy food stuffs like yam, peanuts and beans etc.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth D., who received an education through senior high school, is the mother of two children. She has been selling shoes and flips flops for two years now and is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses and supports her husband when there is any other need. Her loan will be used to increase inventory in order to meet the demand of her customers.  Elizabeth hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards expanding her trade.

loans.use: To increase inventory in order to meet the demand of her customers.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana T., a 33-year-old trader who belongs to a village bank called ‘wonderful Jesus,’ is the mother of five children, four of whom are currently attending school through the help of government free compulsory education. It is her daily dream to provide quality education for her children to give them a better future life. Her husband is a farmer on a palm nuts plantation.

Susana owns and operates a grocery shop selling items including rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, and evaporated milk. She also sells cooking pots, ladles etc., but business progress is limited due to a lack of funds. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With this increased stock, Susana hopes to earn more income to provide for the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Gloria Irene

texts.en:
Gloria, a member of the Sumac Soncco (“Loving heart” in Quechua) Village Bank, is 52 years old and married with seven children, five of whom are adults with their own families and two who still live at home. She has two grandchildren. Gloria sells handbags and purses at a local Saturday market, travelling regularly to Lima and Tacna to buy her merchandise. She has been in this business for more years than she can remember, and derives most of her income from this enterprise. She also sells beer from her home during the week; customers buy beer in one-liter bottles and take them off of the premises to drink.

Gloria is now requesting a loan of 1000 soles to buy more purses to sell. She pledges to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Her dream for the future is to finish educating all of her children.

loans.use: To buy purses and handbags.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O., a 46-year-old member of a village bank called ‘wonderful Jesus,’ is a divorced mother of five children, two currently in school while the rest are working. She resides with her children in Takroase, a farming and mining community in the eastern region of Ghana.

She loves selling goods, the business through which she has been supporting her family for the past two years vending foodstuffs such as tubers of yam, maize and gari. She treks to farming communities such as Techiman to buy her stock, sometimes spending days in the villages just to purchase high quantity products, thereby saving her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell at higher prices. With this loan, Rose wants to buy bulk tubers of yam, maize and gari etc. to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs like yam, peanuts, beans etc.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of five. Currently all her children are in are in school. She loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains her livelihood. She has been selling foodstuffs like plantains, maize, kobe (salt fish), fresh tomatoes, and many more at Takroase for three years now to support her family. Her husband is a cocoa farmer.

She treks to farming communities in and around her village to buy her stock of plantains, yams, salt fish (kobe), maize etc. in bulk from the farmers. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy plantains, yams, tomatoes, kobe, etc. to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school. This would enable her save more to support her husband in taking care of the home. Esther belongs to a village bank called ‘Wonderful Jesus.’

loans.use: Fruits, vegetables, and fish for resale

loans.name: Venturas José

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega, el señor Venturas L. se dedica arduamente a su actividad de transporte de pasajeros de un lugar a otro teniendo su propio triciclo con el cual traslada a sus pasajeros.

EL costo del transporte es depende la distancia y el problema que hoy en día el señor Venturas atraviesa  es que requiere de un crédito para la compra de los repuestos para el triciclo y de esta forma continuar en su actividad para mejoras su nivel de vida y el de su hogar.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinandega, Venturas L. works arduously transporting passengers from one place to another on his cycle rickshaw. The transport fare depends on the distance. Venturas needs credit to purchase replacement parts for his cycle so that he can continue his business and improve his quality of life and his home.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase replacement parts for his cycle rickshaw

loans.name: María Gladis

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega la señora María V. se dedica a laborar arduamente en su pulpería donde a diario comercializa sus productos a sus clientes que le visitan.

Atraviesa la necesidad de suplir de productos a lo inmediato y por esto es que espera ser beneficiada con un crédito en Ceprodel para la compra de dichos productos y de esta manera continuar con el desarrollo de su negocio.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinandega Mrs. Maria V. owns a local store. She works there every day, selling products to her clients. Maria needs to supply products immediately and because of this she hopes to acquire a loan with Ceprodel. She'll use the money to buy products and develop her business.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products

loans.name: Manuel Joaquín

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega, el señor Manuel P. se dedica al negocio de venta de libros y revistas comercializados en su establecimiento que posee actualmente.

Ha logrado salir adelante en el negocio y hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel con el propósito de ser beneficiado con un crédito para la compra de los libros y así continuar en su negocio.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinadega, Mr. Manuel P. works selling books and magazines in his store. He has been able to get ahead and now he comes to Ceprodel asking for a loan to buy books and thereby continue in this business.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy books and magazines

loans.name: Lilliam De Jesús

texts.es:
La señora Lilliam M. se dedica a su negocio de venta de bebidas de todo tipo en su propio establecimiento en la ciudad de Chinandega donde a diario vende sus productos a sus clientes que le visitan.

Hoy en día la razón por la que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de las bebidas y así continuarlas comercializando en su establecimiento. También elabora alimentos que también son comercializados en su localidad por ella misma.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lilliam M. works in her store daily, selling all types of drinks. She lives in works in the city of Cinandega. Now she would like a loan from Ceprodel to buy drinks so as to continue selling them in her store. She also cooks food that she sells in the same store.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy drinks

loans.name: Kwewayo Namukozi Women’S Group

texts.en:
Aisha is asking for 600,000 shillings in loans to support her farming and poultry business. She has been operating this business for 10 years. Her business provides income to pay for her 3 children’s school fees and medical care for her disabled husband, who does not work.

She sells her goods to nearby grocery shops in her village, but plans to use the loan to help start her own shop so that she can sell her goods on her own. She dreams of having a thriving shop so that she can provide comfortable lives for her children and husband.

loans.use: Start a retail poultry shop

loans.name: Cristobal Antonio

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega, el señor Cristobal A. se dedica arduamente a su actividad de servicio de taxi en el sector transporte movilizándose por las calles de Chinandega trasladando pasajeros a diferentes lugares. 

A esta actividad se dedica desde hace 10 años y ha sido el sustento para su hogar. Hoy en día ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con un crédito para la compra de repuestos para el taxi debido a que le urge a lo inmediato repararlo para continuar con su actividad y así llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinandega, Mr. Cristobal A. works hard as a taxi driver, transporting passengers to different places. He's been in this business for 10 years, and as been able to support his household. Now he'd like a loan from Ceprodel to buy replacement parts for his taxi. He'd like to repair it immediately so as to continue working to support his family.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy replacement parts for his taxi

loans.name: José Alfonso

texts.es:
El señor José E. se dedica a laborar en la ciudad de Chinandega en el servicio de triciclo trasladando a las personas de un lugar a otro y de acuerdo con la distancia así es el cobro del pasaje.

Es de importancia destacar que hoy en día él requiere de la inversión en su triciclo y para esto ha acudido a Ceprodel porque necesita la compra de los repuestos para darle el mantenimiento respectivo al triciclo y de esta forma salir adelante en su servicio de triciclo en es sector transporte.
texts.en:
Mr. José E. works in the city of Cinandega as a bicycle rickshaw driver, transporting passengers from one place to another. He charges based on the distance traveled in the journey. José needs to invest in his rickshaw, and he'd like a loan from Ceprodel to buy replacement parts. With the necessary maintenance for his rickshaw, José will get ahead in the transportation sector.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rickshaw repair

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer A. sells ladies clothing and rice at Abura, which she has done for 7 years. Jenifer has received an education through Junior High School. She is married with 2 children and her husband is also employed as a trader.

Jenifer is responsible for paying to clothe and feed her children. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her increase the amount of clothing in order to meet the demand from her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards expanding her trade.

loans.use: Increase clothing inventory

loans.name: Victorina

texts.es: Victorina V. D. R., vive en San  Salvador junto a su esposo y dos nietos. Victorina se dedica  a su negocio que un bazar ubicado en su casa; donD. venD. prendas D. oro, perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y otros. Victorina ya tiene 9 años D. experiencia en su negocio  y una clientela muy estable, sus vecinos saben que si quieren hacer algún regalo el bazar D. Victorina encontraran lo que buscan es por ello que Victorina solicita un crédito, por que desea comprar más variedad D. mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Victorina V. D. R. lives in San Salvador with her husband and two grandchildren. Victorina manages a store, located in her home, where she sells gold jewelry, perfumes, cremes, cosmetics, and other products. She has been in this business for nine years and has a stable client base. Victorina's neighbors know that if they'd like a gift, Victorina's store will have what they're looking for. Victorina would like a loan to buy a greater variety of merchandise to offer her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supply her business

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en: Betty, a mother of 5 children and a widow, owns a tailor shop as well as a farming shop. She has been operating her tailor shop for 8 years.  Her expenses include providing schooling fees for two of her children and paying wages to her employees. She plans to use the loan to pay her employees for her tailor shop. She dreams that one day she will have a thriving businesses and will be able to live comfortably.

loans.use: Tailoring shop payroll

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary N. is married and has 1 child. She has received an education through Junior High School. Mary sells cosmetics at Abura, which she has done for 2 years. Her husband is a trader. Mary uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses and to support her husband when there is any other need. Mary will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the amount of cosmetics for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save towards expanding her trade in cosmetics.

loans.use: Increase cosmetics store inventory

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina O. is 42 year old woman. She is widowed with six children who are currently in school. Her husband died after a prolonged sickness; she spent all her resourced trying save her husband. There is this adage in our Ghanaian language which says ‘Se owuo kuta adeia nkwa ntumi ngye’ which literally means ‘When death is holding something life cannot take it from it’. That is what Regina was trying to do to save her husband but could not.

She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil (produced from palm nuts) for ten years now. In addition to that she is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew. She produces the palm oil and supplies it to food vendors to prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two--that is, after producing palm oil she uses some of the oil to prepare her meals.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts, meat, and rice to increase her efficiency so as to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her family and finance her children’s education. Regina belongs to a village bank called ‘Nkwagyedom’ which literally means savior of the multitude.

loans.use: Ingredients for food production

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr: Melle maïmouna S. est une fille célibataire qui a 31 ans, elle habite au quartier Diamaguène de Thiès  en face la grande mosquée. Elle est commerçante depuis octobre 1998, son commerce consiste à vendre des denrées alimentaires (sucre + lait en poudre) et aussi des habits  pour hommes et femmes. Elle a déjà intégré l’IMCEC et est à son deuxième prêt avec laquelle elle veut renforce son activité. Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice de  80 000 FCFA sur l’ensemble des marchandises. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de rembourser son prêt et satisfaire ses propres besoins sociaux  et le reste elle l’investit dans son commerce.
texts.en:
Miss Maïmouna S. is a single lady of 31; she lives in the Diamaguène neighborhood in Thiès, opposite the big mosque. She has been selling goods since October 1998. She presently sells groceries (sugar and powdered milk) and also clothing for men and women. She has already joined IMCEC and is on her second loan with which she plans to bolster her business. She hopes to make a profit of 80,000 F CFA on the total goods. Her profit will allow her to reimburse her loan and support herself, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering her business

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr: Madame Astou D. a vendu des céréales locales depuis 7 ans dans le village de Diourbel.  Diourbel est une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Avec ce deuxième crédit qu’elle sollicite de l’IMCEC et Kiva, elle va reconstituer son stock de céréales afin de mieux servir ses clients.  Elle est mariée et elle utilise les revenus de son entreprise pour aider son mari avec les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Astou D. has been selling local grains for 7 years in the village of Diourbel. Diourbel is a little rural town situated 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. With this second loan, that she is requesting from IMCEC and Kiva, she is going to replenish her stock of grains in order to better serve her customers. She is married and she uses the income from her business to help her husband support the family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of local grains for re-sale

loans.name: Decadas 2 Group

texts.en:
The Decadas group is made of five new entrepreneurs from San Pedro de Macoris. This is their very first micro-loan. Their business activities are mostly clothing sales and small grocery stores, except for Eustaquio, who has a car and motorcycle repair shop.

Sonia C. was chosen to be the group representative. She and her partner, Rafael, have three children. She will start a clothing business. Her plan is to purchase items like t-shirts, women's blouses, jeans, and undergarments to sell in her neighborhood to her acquaintances. She knows that possibly, people won't buy much at the same time, which is why she plans to keep her sales varied.

Sonia would like to eventually own a house where she and her family can live more comfortably and not pay rent, since this will most likely represent a large portion of her monthly profits.

The members of this group are very excited about this opportunity they have received and believe that it will bring new life to their household economies. Thank you for supporting this Kiva loan!

loans.use: Purchase new clothing to sell

loans.name: David Salomon

texts.es: El señor David tiene 33 años de edad, reside en el barrio Villa Venezuela, su esposa le tiene dos hijos de 8 y 19 años de edad, y trabaja en una empresa de zona franca desempeñándose como operaria, el trabaja como disector de cadáveres y también es soldador desde hace diecinueve años, ya que su papa le enseño a soldar. Este es su octavo crédito en Afodenic y se siente muy contento por que ha podido hacer mejoras a su vivienda. Con este crédito va a comprar materia prima para la elaboración de soldadura eléctrica. Sus planes es poder tener un local para hacer sus trabajos.
texts.en:
David is 33 years old, and lives in the Villa Venezuela neighborhood with his wife. They have two children, ages 19 and 8. David works in a free-trade zone as a dissector of cadavers. He has also worked as a welder for the past nineteen years, since his dad taught him how to weld. This is his eighth loan through Afodenic and he feels very happy, as he has been able to make improvements in his home. With this loan, David will acquire raw materials for his electric welding work. His plan is to have a place to do his job.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase material for electric welding

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou D. confectionne des pagnes pour les revendre à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar.  Les pagnes fait un parti très important de la culture Sénégalaise, et les femmes Sénégalaises sont toujours bien habillées.  Alors, le commerce de Madame D. marche bien.  Elle a fait ce commerce depuis 6 ans, et elle a déjà reçu un premier prêt de 50,000 CFA ($100) auprès de l’IMCEC qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Maintenant elle sollicite ce deuxième crédit pour acheter les pagnes et autres matériels pour son entreprise.  Madame D. est mariée avec des enfants qu’elle soutient avec ses revenus.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou D. makes pagne clothing for resale in Diourbel, a rural town located 150 km from Dakar. Pagnes are a very important part of the culture in Senegal, and Senegalese women are always well dressed. So Ms. D.’s business is doing well. She has been in this business for six years, and she has had an initial loan of 50,000 francs CFA from IMCEC that she repaid. Now she’s requesting this second loan to buy pagnes and other supplies for her enterprise. Ms. D. is married and has children who she supports with her revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics

loans.name: Oscar David

texts.es: Don Oscar alquila videos juegos el cual inicio con préstamo para poder comprar todo lo necesarios, este es su segundo ciclo en Afodenic. Tiene 24 años de edad, soltero y aspira a tener su propia casa y también poder cambiar su vehiculo. Con esta solicitud de crédito es para instalar una sala de video completa para tener más servicios para sus clientes ya que la demanda esta buena y no la cubre. Con esto espera ganar mejores ingresos. Da la gracias a la institución por hacer crecer su negocio y sus objetivos.
texts.en:
Don Oscar rents videos games, which he started with a previous loan he used to buy all the necessary items. This is his second cycle with Afodenic. He is 24 years old, single, and hopes to have his own home and also get a new vehicle. With this credit application, Don Oscar plans to install a full video room to offer more services to his customers, as the demand is already there, and he cannot currently meet it. With this new service, he expects to earn better income. Don Oscar gives thanks to the institution for helping him grow his business and his objectives.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase equipment for a video room

loans.name: Fatou Samb

texts.fr: Madame Fatou Samb D. est une femme Sénégalaise qui a fait le commerce des tissus depuis 5 ans.  Elle habite à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Elle sollicite ce crédit chez l’IMCEC pour reconstituer son stock de tissus pour mieux servir ses clients et réaliser un profit.  Elle est mariee avec des enfants, et elle espère d’utiliser ces profits pour soutenir son mari et leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou Samb D. is a Senegalese woman who has been doing commerce in cloth for five years. She lives in Diourbel, a town located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. She’s requesting this loan from IMCEC to replenish her stock of fabrics to serve her customers better and to realize a profit. She is married and has children. She hopes to use these profits to support her husband and their children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth

loans.name: Norma Maria

texts.es: Doña Norma reside en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de la bloquera Haward 2 c al este, tiene 33 años de edad, su esposo trabaja de conductor y tiene dos hijos de 8 y 10 años de edad que cursan la primaria, su negocio es la venta de ropa y zapato desde hace veintidós años que esta en las ventas, anteriormente trabajaba en zona franca las Mercedes, desempeñándose como operaria de maquina, y ahí logro hacer clientela en la venta de ropa, luego decidió dedicarse solo a la venta de ropa, el cual logro aumentar su inventario y mejorar las ventas, con los prestamos que Afodenic  otorgo. Con este crédito va a comprar ropa y zapatos y productos de cosmético para ofertar  a sus clientes y obtener mejores ventas y ganancias para seguir aumentando su negocio.
texts.en:
Doña Norma lives in the neighborhood of Villa Reconciliation, on the Haward east C 2 block. She is 33 years old, and her husband works as a driver. Doña Norma has two children, ages 8 and 10, who attend primary school. Doña Norma's business is selling clothing and shoes. She has worked for twenty years in sales, and previously worked at the Mercedes "duty-free" zone, as a machine operator. While there, she began to sell clothing, and soon decided to focus solely on selling clothes. Her dedication, alongside her Afodenic loans, improved her inventory and her sales. With this loan, Doña Norma will buy clothes, shoes, and cosmetic products to offer to her clients and improve her sales and profits as she continues to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes, shoes, and cosmetics

loans.name: Kaka

texts.fr: Madame Kaka F. est une femme Sénégalaise qui fait le commerce du tabac.  Elle vend le tabac dans son quartier à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Elle sollicite ce crédit chez l’IMCEC pour reconstituer son stock pour mieux servir ses clients et réaliser un profit.  Elle est mariée, et elle espère d’utiliser les profits pour se soutenir et pour aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Ms. Kaka F. is a Senegalese woman who is in the tobacco business. She sells tobacco in her district in Diourbel, a rural town located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. She’s requesting this loan from IMCEC to replenish her stock in order to serve her customers better and to realize a profit. She is married, and she hopes to use the profits to support herself and to help her husband with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tobacco

loans.name: Flor De Fatima

texts.es: Doña Flor tiene 43 años de edad, es Maestra de la secundaria, reside en el barrio Laureles Sur, su esposo se desempeña como bodeguero, tiene dos hijos de 18 y 20 años de edad, la señora Fátima con esta solicitud de crédito va a comprar materiales de construcción para hacer el porche de su casa, y poder gozar de los esfuerzos producido de su trabajo, este es su octavo crédito en Afodenic el cual se ha beneficiado para hacer sus proyectos de mejoras de vivienda a largo plazo. Espera en un futuro poder seguir trabajando con la institución.
texts.en:
Doña Flor is a 43 year old high school teacher, and lives in the South Laureles neighborhood. Her husband works as a winemaker. Doña Flor has two children, ages 18 and 20. With this loan, Doña Flor will acquire construction materials in order to make a porch for her home, and enjoy the efforts of her work. This is her eighth loan with Afodenic, which has helped her improve her home over the long term. She hopes to continue working with Afodenic in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materiales to build a porch for her home

loans.name: Kou

texts.fr: Madame Kou G. est une femme Sénégalaise célibataire qui est actuellement monitrice.  Elle sollicite un crédit chez l’IMCEC et Kiva pour se lancer dans le commerce des produits cosmétiques.  Avec les revenus de ce nouveau entreprise elle espère de mieux se soutenir et d’être indépendante.  Elle attendait le financement de son crédit pour acheter la marchandise, alors il n’y a pas de marchandise dans sa photo.  Madame G. habite à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.
texts.en:
Ms. Kou G. is an unmarried Senegalese woman who is currently a counselor. She’s requesting a loan from IMCEC and Kiva to get started in the commerce of cosmetics. With the revenues from this new enterprise, she hopes to support herself better and to be independent. She was waiting for her loan to be financed to buy merchandise, so no merchandise appears in the photo. Ms. G. lives in Diourbel, a rural town located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Armando Enrique

texts.es: Don Armando se dedica a la toma de fotografía desde hace veintiún años, el inicio tomando fotos en la iglesia, luego compro mejores equipos para obtener utilidades y ofrecer su servicio a sus clientes, tiene 44 años de edad, reside en el barrio Carlos Núñez en la ciudad de Managua, su esposa le tiene un hijo de 18 años de edad, el cual estudia, ella vende cosmético. Este es su sexto crédito en Afodenic el cual va invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción para poner techo a un cuarto.  Sus planes es poder seguir haciendo mejoras a su casa, promocionar su trabajo para captar clientes. Da las gracias a la institución por el apoyo que ha brindado a su familia.
texts.en:
Don Armando has been a photographer for the past 21 years. He began by taking photos at church, and soon after bought better equipment to offer his services to clients. Don Armando is 44 years old, and lives in the Carlos Núñez neighborhood of Managua. He and his wife have an 18 year old son who is studying. His wife sells cosmetics. This is his 6th loan with Afodenic, which he plans to use to buy construction materials to build a roof over a room in his house. He also plans to continue improving his house and promote his work to gain more clients. He would like to thank Afodenic for the support it has given his family.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a roof over a room in his house

loans.name: Decadas 1 Group

texts.en:
The five entrepreneurs applying for this Kiva loan have already paid back two loans to Esperanza International over 6-month terms. This third loan will be used to strengthen their businesses' inventories, which will hopefully produce higher sales volumes.

Milagros P. is the group representative, and her business consists of selling charcoal. In the impoverished area where she lives, many people do not have a stove to cook on or cannot afford gas. Their option is to cook the little food they have in aluminum pots and pans over charcoal fires. Milagros has managed to develop a faithful clientèle and hopes to continue providing charcoal to them by buying more with this loan.

Milagros's greatest ambition is to contribute to the education of her four children attending school by supporting them for as long as they wish to continue studying. Her hopes are that through education they can access better employment opportunities.

Please help us to continue supporting these five micro entrepreneurs. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Momar

texts.fr: Papa Momar F. est un homme Sénégalais qui vend des ustensiles de cuisine depuis plus de 10 ans, donc il est bien expérimenté dans le domaine.  Il a eu à contracter un premier prêt de 200,000 CFA ($400) qu’il a bien remboursé.  Maintenant il sollicite un deuxième crédit chez l’IMCEC et Kiva pour renforcer son commerce.  Monsieur F. habite à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.
texts.en:
Papa Momar F. is a Senegalese man who has been selling kitchen utensils for over ten years, so he is very experienced in this domain. He had to take out an initial loan of 200,000 francs CFA that he has repaid. Now he’s requesting a second loan with IMCEC and Kiva in order to bolster his business. He lives in Diourbel, a rural town located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils

loans.name: Lothy Mercedes

texts.es:
La Sra. LOTHY MERCEDES B. G., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Talentosas”  con su local ubicado en el Jr. Tarapaca Nº 713 del Distrito de Calleria; tiene 35 años, 03 hijos menores, y su esposo es Ing. de una empresa Privada.

Ella se dedica a la crianza de animales menores, paralelamente se hace cargo del alquiler de un local comercial ubicado en pleno centro de la ciudad:  Es socia en Manuela Ramos desde hace 4 años, su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, lo empleo para la crianza de pollos, negocio que le rinde buenas utilidades hasta el día de hoy.

Con este préstamo de S/.1200.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará más aves y su respectivo alimento balanceado ya que se acercan las fiestas de San Juan, época donde hay mayor demanda.

Dice que Manuela Ramos es una institución bien organizada que nos brinda apoyo y capacitación constante lo cual nos permite sacar a delante a nuestras familias..
texts.en:
Mrs. Lothy Mercedes B. G. belongs to the community bank "Talented Women" at its Jr. Tarapaca Nº 713 location in the Calleria District. She is 35 years old, and has 3 children with her husband, who is an engineer at a private company. Lothy works raising small animals, and is also in charge of renting out a commercial space in the center of the city. She has been a member of Manuela Ramos for the past 4 years. She used her first loans of 300 Peruvian Soles to raise chickens, which has been profitable up until today. With this loan of 1200 Peruvian Soles, she will buy more birds and bird feed to sell during the San Juan Festival, when her demand is highest. Mrs. Lothy says that Manuela Ramos is a well-organized institution that gives constant support and training, which greatly helps the participating families.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy birds and bird feed

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: La señora Maria Auxiliadora tiene 44 años de edad, vende frutas y verduras desde hace quince años que inicio con fondos propios, con la iniciativa de  apoyar a su esposo, ya que el vende y compra leña, ella reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino y tiene cinco hijos de 4, 5, 8, 12, y 14 años de edad, es por eso que se preocupa por el futuro de sus hijos para que no les falte el alimento y los estudios. Con esta solicitud de crédito es su tercer ciclo en Afodenic que ha sido de muchos beneficios para su hogar, con este préstamo quiere comprar un caballo para vender sus verduras ya que ella vende en su casa de habitación y ambulante, pero desea vender mas y que se le haga mas fácil el transporte, el cual le permitirá mayor de venta y ganancias para mejorar sus necesidades.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria Auxiliadora is a 44-year-old woman who has been selling fruits and vegetables for a living for fifteen years. She started out with her own funds with the aim of helping her husband, who buys and sells firewood. She lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood and has five children ages 4, 5, 8, 12, and 14, which is why she is so worried about her children having both food and an education. This is her third loan request from Afodenic, which has brought her household many benefits. With this loan, she would like to purchase a horse so that she can sell her produce because she currently works both from her house and as a street vendor. However, she would like to increase sales and facilitate transportation, which will allow her to boost profits and pay for what her family needs.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a horse to become a street vendor

loans.name: Dios Todo Lo Puede - Group 3

texts.en:
Paula G. owns what is called a fantasia in the Dominican Republic. It is a small store mostly dedicated to offering personal care products, accessories and school supplies. With this loan, Paula will ensure her fantasia is properly stocked for the months to come. She hopes to expand her business to transform it into a department store in the future. Her greatest ambition is to see her children practicing professional careers of their choice. She has four children: ages 19, 14, 13 and 11.

Paula has been appointed the group coordinator of this group of five entrepreneurs from San Pedro de Macoris. They are starting their microfinance venture with this Kiva loan. These are people who have been involved in trade activities for some time but who do not have financial support to sustain their businesses through the current economic situation.

Please help us support these new microentrepreneurs with a Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase articles for her store

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Unidas se dio mediante invitación que realizaron las señoras del comité. La familia de Villa Salvador de la ciudad de Areguá a sus vecinas y amigas a formar un nuevo comité, las señoras del Asentamiento Evenecer también de la ciudad de Areguá decidieron formar un comité el cual actualmente está conformado por 18 integrantes y se encuentran en el tercer ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras del la Fundación Paraguaya.

La señora Lucia M. se dedica a la venta de carbón e invirtió el dinero en la compra de carbón al por mayor para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Rossana González se dedica a la veterinaria e invirtió el dinero en la compra de medicamentos para animales.


La señora Edilsa Fariña se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas al por mayor para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Aurelia S. se dedica a la venta de comestibles e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de los mismos.

La señora Erma López se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas al por mayor para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Nilse Ramírez se dedica a la venta de bebidas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Ignacia Giménez se dedica a la venta de comestibles e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de los mismos.

La señora Jorgelina González tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para surtir su negocio.

La señora Victoria Bordón se dedica a la venta de comestibles e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de los mismos.

La señora Ceferina Leguizamón se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de frutas variables para su venta.

La señora Irma M. tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para surtir su negocio.

La señora Epifanía V. González se dedica a la lavandería e invirtió el dinero en el arreglo de su lavarropas.

La señora Elsa E. se dedica a la venta de sabanas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de telas e hilos para la confección de los mismos.

La señora Tomasa Dávalos tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para surtir su negocio.

La señora Liz Karina González se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías varias para la venta de los mismos.

La señora Cintia González se dedica a la venta de hierbas medicinales e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para su venta.

La señora María Isabel S. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de más mercaderías para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora María Emilce Dávalos tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
The committee of "United Women" was formed by invitation, made by the ladies of the committee. The Villa Salvador family of Areguá city, with their friends and neighbors, formed a new committee. The women of the Evenecer settlement in Areguá city also decided to form a committee, which currently consists of 18 members, and is in its third cycle of the program "Committee of Women Entrepreneurs of the Paraguay Foundation". Below is a list of the participants, and their businesses: Mrs. Lucia M. sells coal, and invested her loan money in the purchase of coal at wholesale prices to increase her business. Mrs. Rossana G. works in veterinary medicine, and invested her loan money in the purchase of medicine for animals. Mrs. Edilsa Fariña, Mrs. Erma L., and Mrs. Liz Karina G. all sell clothes independently, and invested their loan money in buying clothes at wholesale prices to increase their sales. Mrs. Aurelia S. and Mrs. Ignacia Giménez both sell groceries independently, and invested their loan money in the purchase of inputs for their respective establishments. Mrs. Nilse R. sells drinks, and invested her loan money in the purchase of goods to increase her sales. Mrs. Victoria Bordón sell groceries, and invested her loan money in the purchase of inputs for her establishment. Mrs. Ceferina Leguizamón sells fruit, and invested her loan money in the purchase of fruits to sell. Mrs. V. González Epiphany works with laundry, and invested her loan money in the repair of her washing machine. Mrs. Elsa E. sells sheets, and invested her loan money in the purchase of fabrics and yarns to manufacture more sheets. Mrs. Tomasa Dávalos, Mrs. Mary Emilce Dávalos, Mrss Irma M., and Mrs. Jorgelina G. all have pantries, and invested their money in buying goods to sell through their business. Mrs. Cintia González sells medicinal herbs, and invested her money in purchasing supplies for sale. Mrs. Mary Isabel S. sells candy, and invested her money into buying more merchandise to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various goods to be sold through members' respective businesses

texts.es: Yolanda F. vive en Santa Tecla es madre soltera de dos hijos adolecentes, Yolanda se dedica a la venta de granos básicos, tiene un pequeño local donde hay mucha afluencia de personas, tiene una clientela muy estable  ya que sus precios son muy competitivos; los hijos de Yolanda estudian en la escuela y al salir de sus clases se van al negocio a ayudar. Yolanda solicita un préstamo, el cual será de muchos beneficios en su familia, ya que es ella es único sostén familiar, Yolanda solicita este crédito para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Yolanda F. lives in Santa Tecla and is a single mother of two adolescents. She sells staple grains for a living. She has a small business space where she receives a steady flow of customers because of her competitive prices. Yolanda’s children currently attend school, but once they leave school, they go to the shop and help her. Yolanda is requesting a loan that will be greatly beneficial to her family, as she is the sole source of income. Yolanda needs the loan in order to restock her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Dinora Del Socorro

texts.es: La señora Dinora ha sido una mujer esforzada desde muy joven ayudaba a sus padres para apoyarles. Su negocio es una pulpería,  que desde hace cinco años administra, también vende estufas que su esposo hace. Anteriormente vendía ropa pero tiene mejores ingreso con la venta ya que vende variedad. Tiene 64 años de edad, sus hijos son mayores de edad y residen independientes, ella habita en el barrio Hialeah en la ciudad de Managua, su esposo elabora estufas eléctricas lo cual es de gran apoyo. Este es el décimo crédito en Afodenic el cual va invertir en compras varias como: granos básicos, carnes y productos de limpiezas para incrementar el volumen de inventario, como sus ventas.
texts.en:
Dinora has been a hardworking woman since she was very young, helping out her parents in order to support them. Her business is a local general store that she has run for 5 years. She also sells electric stoves her husband makes. While she used to sell clothing, she makes more money now since she sells a larger variety of products. She is 64 years old with grown, independent sons, and lives in the Hialeah neighborhood of Managua. This is her tenth loan with Afodenic which she will use to buy various goods such as basic grains, meats, and cleaning products to expand her inventory and sales.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain, meat, and cleaning products for her store

loans.name: Maria Eugenia

texts.es: Doña Maria Eugenia, reside en el barrio Martin Luther King en la ciudad de Managua, tiene 33 años de edad, su esposo es promotor de crédito, con tres hermosos hijos que están estudiando, ella tiene un cafetín en un mercado de la capital, se llama mercado oriental, y es uno de lo mas visitados por los Nicaragüenses por su variedad de productos y bajos precios, inicio con la experiencia que adquirió de su mama, y ahorros propio compro el cafetín, lleva trece años administrándolo. Con este crédito quiere invertir en construcción pues desea terminar de construir un cuarto para sus hijos para que estén en mejor condición, uno de sus mejores deseos es poder terminar su casa, da las gracias Afodenic por el beneficio  y el apoyo. A futuro espera tener nuevos segmento de mercado y poder dar estudios a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maria Eugenia lives in the Martin Luther King neighborhood of Managua. She is 33 years old, with three beautiful children who are in school. Her husband is a loan officer. She owns a coffee shop in the capital's Mercado Oriental, one of the most visited by Nicaraguans for its variety and low prices. She began with the experience she had learned from her mother and bought the shop with her own savings. She has spent three years running her business. With this loan she hopes to build a room for her children; one of her greatest wishes is to be able to finish her house. She thanks Afodenic for their benefits and support. In the future she hopes to have a new market segment and be able to provide for her children's education.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to finish a room for her children

loans.name: Petrona Del Carmen

texts.es: Petrona del Carmen H. C. vive en San Martin junto a su s dos hijas. Petrona se dedica a su negocio, donde vende diversos productos como; papel higiénico, detergentes, aceite, entre otros. Petrona tiene ya siete años en el negocio, donde poco a poco ha ido creciendo y ganando clientela; pero el sueño de Petrona es vender al por mayor, porque de esa manera obtendría un margen más grande de ganancias, del que ve hasta este momento vendiendo al detalle, es por ello que Petrona solicita un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad de mercadería y ofertarla al por mayor.
texts.en:
Petrona del Carmen H. C. lives in San Martin with her two daughters. Petrona has her own business selling various products such as toilet paper, detergent, and oil, among others. She has had seven years of experience, growing and gaining customers little by little. Her dream is to sell wholesale goods, since she would earn a larger margin. So far she has been selling individual goods; this is why Petrona would like a loan to buy a larger quantity of merchandise to sell wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy larger quantities of inventory

loans.name: Esther - Groups 1 & 4

texts.en:
Cristina A. and Josefina D. L. S. are the group coordinators of the two groups participating in this Kiva loan. Each group is maD. up of five micro-entrepreneurs. Cristina is married with no children; Josefina lives with her husband Jose Luis and has two children.

Josefina is an Avon representative, selling cosmetics. She also sells undergarments at her house. She will use the loan to purchase cosmetics from Avon's new campaign as well as to buy women's undergarments and men's underwear packages for sale. Cristina sells similar products at a small store at her house.

Cristina and Josefina represent women who deciD. to start small businesses to supplement the insufficient incomes their households receive. They both hope their businesses will help them become financially independent. Neither of them received enough support from their families to complete their schooling - therefore, neither of them completed school. Josefina does not want that for her children: she hopes to be successful ebough to support her children's education. Cristina hopes to continue her own education by taking a few technical courses; she plans on paying for these with some of her profits.

Please help us support these micro-entrepreneurs with this Kiva loan.

Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to sell from Avon's new campaign as well as buying undergarments for sale.

loans.name: Glinis Guadalupe

texts.es: La señora Glenis  Guadalupe López, tiene la edad, de 35 años, reside en el barrio Hialeah VI etapa en la ciudad de Managua, tiene dos hijos de 13 y 16 años de edad, su esposo es albañil, vende granos básicos, gaseosa y golosinas es una pequeña pulpería que espera que cada día crezca mas, tiene seis años de administrarla la cual inicio con fondos que su esposo dio, este es su segundo ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en la remodelación del negocio ya que es pequeño, sus planes es poder invertir mas en el inventario para captar clientes, y poder dar estudio a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Glenis Guadalupe López is 35 years old and lives in the Hialeah VI neighborhood of Managua. She has two children, 13 and 16. Her husband is a builder. She sells basic grains, soda, and sweets in a small general store that she hopes will grow every day. She started out with funds from her husband and has six years of experience. This is her second loan with Afodenic, which she will use to remodel her store since it is small. She plans to be able to invest more in her inventory in order to attract clients and provide for her children's education.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to remodel her small business

loans.name: Madres Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité Madres Unidas se dio mediante la formación del comité Mujeres Unidas del Asentamiento Evenecer del Barrio Caacupemi de la ciudad de Aregua. El comite habia iniciado con 20 integrantes por lo que las señoras vecinas del barrio que tambien querian formar parte del comité decidiero formar un nuevo grupo. Actualmente el comité está conformado por 20 integrantes y se encuentran en el tercer ciclo del programa de Mujeres Emprendadoras de Fundacion Paraguaya.

La señora Rosa L. se dedica a la venta de bijouterie e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderias para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Delia F. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderias para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Daysi F. tiene una despensa e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderias para surtir su negocio.

La señora Maria Luordes O. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderias para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Juana F. se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas al por mayor para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Maria Nilce M. se dedica al reciclaje e invirtio el dinero en la compra de plasticos para su venta posterior.

La señora Eugenia G. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderias para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Cirila V. se dedica a la venta de hierbas medicinales e invirtio el dinero en la compra de insumos para su venta.

La señora Amada A. se dedica a la venta de masas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboracion de los mismos.

La señora Gloria A. se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de frutas variables para su venta.
 
La señora Clara Báez se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de frutas variables para su venta.

La señora Juana Rojas se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtio el dinero en la compra de frutas variables para su venta.

La señora Maria Elizabeth M. se dedica al reciclaje e invirtio el dinero en la compra de plasticos para su venta posterior.

La señora Myrian M. se dedica a la venta de merceria e invirtio su dinero en la compra de mercaderias al por mayor para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Francisca R. tiene una despensa e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderias para surtir su negocio.

La señora Gavina U. se dedica a la venta de globos a gas juguetes e  invirtio el dinero en la compra insumos para la elaboracion y venta de los mismos.

La señora Maria Alicia F. se dedica a la venta de lenceria e invirtio el dinero en la compra de lenceria variables al por mayor para su venta.

La señora Emiliana N. se dedica a la venta de lenceria e invirtio el dinero en la compra de lenceria variables al por mayor para su venta.

La señora Palmira G. se dedica a la venta de merceria e invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderias para su venta.

La señora Edith L. se dedica a la venta de miel e invirtio el dinero en la compra al por mayor para su venta.
texts.en:
The Madres Unidas (United Mothers) committee was formed through the Mujeres Unidas del Asentamiento Evenecer committee from the Caacupemi neighborhood in the city of Aregua. They began with twenty members since neighborhood women who also wanted to be a part of the committee decided to form a new group. The committee is satisfied with its 20 members; this is its third loan cycle with the Mujeres Emprendadoras de Fundación Paraguaya (Women Entrepreneurs of the Fundación Paraguaya). Rosa L. sells bijouterie and will spend the money to buy more merchandise and raise sales. Delia F. sells sweets and will spend the money to buy merchandise for her sales. Daysi F. owns a pantry and will spend the money to buy merchandise for her business. Maria Lourdes O. sells sweets and will spend the money on more merchandise. Juana F. sells clothes and will spend the money to buy wholesale clothes. Maria Nilce M. runs a recycling business and will spend the money to buy plastic for subsequent sales. Eugenia G. sells sweets and will spend the money to buy more merchandise. Cirila V. sells medicinal herbs and will spend the money to buy more supplies. Amada A. sells pastries and will spend the money to buy cooking materials. Gloria A. sells fruit and will spend the money to buy various fruits to sell.
